intro: Quercus rubra var. texana, commonly known as the Texas red oak, is a variant of the northern red oak native to the southern United States. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters, featuring a broad, rounded crown and a sturdy trunk. Its leaves are lobed, with pointed tips and a deep green color during the growing season, turning reddish-brown in the fall. The tree produces small, cup-shaped acorns that are an important food source for various wildlife species. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in woodland areas and along riverbanks.
